node.title: Evictions are mounting in the United States, but at a slower pace than many tenants and advocates feared.
node.alt: Eviction proceedings are rising across the country, leading tenants like these in Indianapolis earlier this month to seek legal help.
node.content: ["In Indianapolis, eviction courts are packed as judges make their way through a monthslong backlog of cases. In Detroit, advocates are rushing to knock on the doors of tenants facing possible eviction. In Gainesville, Fla., landlords are filing evictions at a rapid pace as displaced tenants resort to relatives\u2019 couches for places to sleep or seek cheaper rents outside the city.", "It is not the sudden surge of evictions that tenants and advocates feared after the Supreme Court ruled in August that President Biden\u2019s extension of the eviction moratorium was unconstitutional. Instead, what\u2019s emerging is a more gradual eviction crisis that is increasingly hitting communities across the country, especially those where the distribution of federal rental assistance has been slow, and where tenants have few protections.", "\u201cFor months we all used these terms like eviction \u2018tsunami\u2019 and \u2018falling off the cliff,\u2019\u201d said Lee Camp, an attorney who represents tenants facing eviction in St. Louis. But those simple terms missed the complexity of the eviction process and the lack of reliable statistics to track it, he said. \u201cIt was not going to happen overnight. Certainly it would take weeks and months to play out.\u201d", "And even now, experts say, the available numbers dramatically undercount the number of tenants being forced from their homes either through court-ordered evictions or informal ones, especially as rising rents make seeking new tenants increasingly profitable for landlords."]
